title: Daniel Camarena
text:
Daniel Ricardo Camarena (born November 9, 1992) is an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> in the <a href="San%20Diego%20Padres">San Diego Padres</a> organization. He has played in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> (MLB) for the Padres. He was drafted by the <a href="New%20York%20Yankees">New York Yankees</a> in the 20th round of the <a href="2011%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20draft">2011 Major League Baseball draft</a>. Listed at and , he throws and bats left-handed. Camarena spent a day on the <a href="2019%20New%20York%20Yankees%20season">Yankees'</a> active roster in 2019, but did not appear in a game, earning him the distinction of being a "<a href="phantom%20ballplayer">phantom ballplayer</a>". He remained a phantom ballplayer until he made his MLB debut with the Padres in 2021. On July 8, 2021, he became the first <a href="relief%20pitcher">relief pitcher</a> to hit a <a href="grand%20slam%20%28baseball%29">grand slam</a> since 1985, and the first pitcher since 1898 to do so on his first <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hit</a>.
Career.
New York Yankees.
Camarena was drafted by the <a href="New%20York%20Yankees">New York Yankees</a> in the 20th round, 629th overall, of the <a href="2011%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20draft">2011 Major League Baseball draft</a> out of <a href="Cathedral%20Catholic%20High%20School">Cathedral Catholic High School</a>. On August 16, 2011, Camarena signed with the Yankees over slot value, signing for $335K.
On July 6, 2019, Camarena was selected to the 40-man roster and promoted to the major leagues for the first time. However, he was optioned to Triple-A the next day without appearing in a game. On August 13, 2019, Camarena was released by the Yankees organization.
San Diego Padres.
On February 13, 2020, Camarena signed a minor league contract with the <a href="San%20Diego%20Padres">San Diego Padres</a> organization. He did not play in a game in 2020 due to the cancellation of the minor league season because of the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>.
On July 19, 2020, Camarena was added to the Padres’ 60-man player pool for the pandemic-shortened season, but spent the year at the alternate training site without making an MLB appearance. He was assigned to the Triple-A <a href="El%20Paso%20Chihuahuas">El Paso Chihuahuas</a> to begin the 2021 season.
Camerena was named the <a href="Triple-A%20West">Triple-A West</a> pitcher of the week for the week of June 7–13, 2021. On June 18, the Padres' added Camarena to their <a href="taxi%20squad">taxi squad</a>. The next day, he was selected to the active roster. He made his MLB debut that day against the <a href="Cincinnati%20Reds">Cincinnati Reds</a>, pitching 2.2 innings and allowing 3 earned runs. In the game, he also notched his first career strikeout, punching out Reds infielder <a href="Mike%20Freeman%20%28baseball%29">Mike Freeman</a>.
On July 8, 2021, Camarena hit a <a href="grand%20slam%20%28baseball%29">grand slam</a> off <a href="Washington%20Nationals">Washington Nationals</a> pitcher <a href="Max%20Scherzer">Max Scherzer</a>, sparking a comeback from an 2–8 deficit which resulted in a 9–8 win for the Padres. This made Camarena the first MLB <a href="relief%20pitcher">relief pitcher</a> to hit a grand slam since <a href="Don%20Robinson%20%28baseball%29">Don Robinson</a> in 1985, and the first pitcher to hit a grand slam for his first career hit since <a href="Bill%20Duggleby">Bill Duggleby</a> of the <a href="Philadelphia%20Phillies">Philadelphia Phillies</a> in 1898, and the second Padres pitcher since <a href="Mike%20Corkins">Mike Corkins</a> who hit one off the Reds in 1970.
